PrimEcoSys: South Texas Dune and Coastal Grassland

habitat_description:
The range of this species expands from south Texas and adjacent Alamos, Sonora with a continuous distribution from central Nuevo Leon and central Sinaloa to Costa Rica (Conant and Collins 1998). The disjunct population of Texas, where this species occurs, extends across the counties of Hidalgo, Cameron, and Starr following the Rio Grande; but also Aransas and Refugio along the Coast (Dixon 2000).

Spends most of its time hiding under shelter such as fallen palm trees, trash of packrat nests, and burrows (Conant and Collins 1998). Habitat can be savanna, warm temperate and tropical thornscrub, pasturelands, and open woodlands (Lannoo 2005). Areas with shortgrass cover are preferred and they only emerge from their underground cover after prolonged rains (Lannoo 2005). Found in moist areas within arid regions. Uses rocks, leaf litter, and underground burrows for cover usually along margins of marshes and ponds (Behler and King 1979). Temporary wetlands are used during breeding following rains (Lannoo 2005).

Shortgrass savannah, warm temperate or tropical thronscrub.
